text: today we're gonna make a solid metal
coyote skull I recently bought a house
in Joshua Tree from my sister
Jesse and I wanted to make her a
housewarming gift that would represent
the desert environment and the coyote
skull door knocker seemed to make sense
so I bought a couple of skulls they're
about $15 each I got him at a store
called Paxton gate in San Francisco and
you was gonna make a urethane mold
around one of these skulls but because
the teeth and all the little pockets I
was worried that the mold making
material would grab on to all these
little nooks and crannies so I did a
little bit of coyote dentistry with my
rio b rotary tool this is really awesome
there's a flexible shaft so it's very
easy to control the spinning head he's
modeling clay to fill in some of the
deep pockets and gaps that would cause
the mold making material that gets stuck
I also beefed up the orbital socket
bones that were around where the eye
goes
i hot glued on some popsicle sticks to
kind of raised the skull up so that i
could glue it flap down to a piece of
melamine I glued it down securely
because I don't want it to float up when
I pour the mold making material over it
and then I use modeling clay to kind of
smooth out the contours so there would
have an easier time removing the skull
from the mold without breaking it
I hot-glued some scrap pieces of wood
around the skull and was ready to start
mixing the mold making material
I'm using mold max 60 from smooth-on
it's a two-part high-temperature mold
making material that hardens after you
mix the two parts together while I was
mixing it I decide to make molds for a
couple other items as well but and those
may end up as projects in the future
after letting it cure for a couple of
days I then stripped away the hot glue
and began the process of removing the
skull from the mold now in the past for
concrete casting projects I've used
materials like mold star 30 which is a
lot more flexible and makes it really
easy to remove the original item from
the mold but that material doesn't have
the same temperature durability as this
stuff and this stuff is also not quite
as flexible so removing the skull was a
little bit difficult after struggling
for a while I realized I was gonna have
to cut the mold all the way open this
isn't ideal but it just means I'll have
to really press it together nice and
tight when I do the molten metal process
all right so I cleaned out the mold
which is now in two pieces and was ready
to start melting the metal
I just duct-taped a few scrap pieces of
wood around it to hold the pieces
together nice and tight
the metal I'm using is an alloy made out
of tin and business I'll put a link to
it in the description box below I like
this material because it's lead-free and
melts at really low temperatures just
around two hundred and eighty degrees so
I don't need a furnace or any specialty
equipment like that I just used this
really cheap melting pot that I got from
Amazon now I want the eye sockets to be
hollow so I didn't pour it all the way
full and made sure they could still see
some red from the mold through where the
eye sockets are alright well while we're
waiting for the metal to cool let me

to the build once the metal had cooled I
removed the duct tape and ripped the tin
skull right out of the mold
it was now ready to work on the mounting
plate and hinge for the door knocker I
traced the outline of the skull on a
piece of 1/8 inch thick steel and then
cut it out with my angle grinder
I also took off most of the rust and
mill scale and rounded over the edges as
well
I drill the hole through a piece of flat
bar
and they gave it a nice radius with my
angle grinder with a flap disc
and then welded this little tab to the
mounting plate
you
and then marked a location on the back
of the metal skull and then started
drilling through the tin to remove the
material to make a place for the hinge
tin is relatively soft and I had a nice
sharp drill bit so this wasn't that
difficult
once I had drilled out a nice slot I
placed the skull and then drill the hole
through the side so that I could put a
bolt through so that everything would
swing nicely
I had it mounted with the bolt I could
then see that the mounting plate was a
little bit too long so I just trimmed
that down
i primed the mounting plate with two
coats of rust-oleum rusty metal primer
before doing a finished paint job with
this really nice light gray color also
from resto Liam
the head of the bolt wasn't sitting
flush to the skull so I used my rotary
Carver guests to remove a little bit so
they could sit nice and flat
I also used this handy tool to trim the
bolt as well
Jesse's front door isn't ready yet so I
just screwed the mounting plate to the
wall to test it out the bolt fit in
nicely and this heavy-duty five-pound
door knocker sounds great this project
is a little bit silly but I do like the
idea people organic objects that relate
to the environment that you're in and
turning them into semi useful objects
this is also just a great way to really
define to set the tone for an aesthetic
